bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, September 12, 1940

div1.p: Hench expresses great interest in reading Truby's paper. He requests the address of Emilie Lawrence Reed and Blossom Reed. He discusses the dinner honoring Moran at the University of Virginia, and he invites Kean to attend the dedication of the Lazear Memorial Building.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, September 12, 1940
div1.opener:
September 12, 1940
General Jefferson R. Kean
2804 N. Street N. W.
Georgetown
Washington, D. C.
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
I am so glad my memorandum and photographs arrived safely but my
conscience hurts me at the amount of work I am asking you to do. My only defence is
that it is in behalf of a cause that is so dear to your heart.

I should love to see General Truby's complete sketch. I agree with you
that his contribution will be most important and has a participant his remarks will be of
infinitely greater importance than any I could publish. Do you know where he plans to pub-
lish it, as a book or in a medical journal? He only sent me a page of abstracts and I am
delighted to have that for my Washington and Jefferson speech. I was interested to hear
of your recent conversation with General Ireland and you state that since then you wrote to
Mrs. Walter Reed. I did not know she was living and I am most anxious to get her address.
You say her daughter answered. I would appreciate it greatly to have the addresses of both
of these people. So far, I have been

May I again beg of you for once to cast off your long worn cloak of
modesty and tell me in as intimate detail as you are willing, of the various ways you helped
Dr. Reed and the commission. The amount of material I am getting is growing and the story
becomes daily more fascinating. I am of the mind to make this a hobby, to keep on investi-
gating the matter and publish my researches not only in the form of a medical article but
perhaps even in the form of a book, at some distant future time, and it is only fair to you
and to your family that, in the third person, your contribution can be spoken of with dignity
and the full truth.

I am delighted to know that the medical faculty at the University of
Virginia are giving Moran a dinner. I had a modest hand in this. In Havana, he spoke
wistfully of his desire to see the University again. I made a note of this and after leaving
Washington, I went to Charlottesville and spoke to a couple of individuals, telling them
that Moran might be in the States on the twenty-sixth of October. I am delighted at the
result of this conversation. Perhaps I told you that my brother is Professor of English
Literature at the University of Virginia and has been there for about eighteen years.
He married a local girl of the Michie family, long associated with the history of that
part of Virginia. I wish indeed that I could attend this dinner, but as I will be seeing
Moran in Washington, Pennsylvania a few days later, I think I will have to forego the
pleasure.

I am most anxious to have your data from the diary. Although I have
read much of the epidemic of yellow fever in Cuba, your simply written notes brought the
tragedy more forcefully to my mind than anything I have read. I will appreciate it if
you could amplify your diary, and dictate to the stenographer the general reaction of the
army and the people of Havana to that particular epidemic. With citizens and soldiers dying
right and left, was there much panic, quiet fear, or was it all accepted fatalistically?
General Jefferson R. Kean
- 2 -
September 12, 1940
You will note that I did not include the interesting story which you told me about
interviewing your friend with yellow fever through the window, with you on the porch.
It is such little anecdotes that bring a story to life, and if you are willing for
me to insert that, I shall be delighted to use it.

I am sending you by separate post a photograph of the Lazear Memorial
Building, to be dedicated at Washington and Jefferson College, Washington, Pennsylvania.
I think it is a lovely building. Would you be able to attend this affair? I know that
they expect to invite Moran and Kissinger, and confidentially, funds are being raised
to pay their expenses. I fear that these funds would not cover the traveling expenses
of others, even one as closely associated with the work as you were, but I am absolutely
certain that the President would be highly honored to send you an invitation if you
thought you could attend the affair. Washington is about thirty miles from Pittsburgh.
It is a small college of about five hundred and not overly pretentious, but is rich in
tradition and prominent alumni. It is the oldest college west of the Allegheny Mountains.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
P. S. I just had a letter from Dr. C. R. Finlay of Havana, Dr.
Carlos Finlay's son. I believe I told you that he was publishing a book, in English,
on his father's work. He tells me that it is just off the press and I am sending for
a copy at once, to the Oxford University Press, 114 Fifth Ave., New York City.
